entry.title: Re: impossible to add document for virtual assets and non...
entry.content:
Hi @Joo_Leo 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through possible scenarios.

The reason you are facing the issue lies in the fact that, in SAP Business One, you cannot mix virtual assets and regular items or non-virtual assets in the same document. SAP explicitly blocks this to ensure correct asset capitalization and inventory management.

You have the possibility to resolve the issue by creating separate purchase orders. One for virtual assets and another for regular inventory items or non-virtual assets

Please ensure to review your purchase order. If it includes both types of items, split them into different documents as required. If you are unsure which items are classified as virtual assets, I suggest you check the asset settings or consult asset master data for items marked with the virtual asset flag.

If this error still persists for items you believe are not virtual assets, please ensure to review their definitions and ensure proper field setup per SAP guidelines.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: ABAP Extensibility Guide â€“ Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - August 2025 Update
entry.content:
Hi Community,

"

  • Level B can be achieved by custom extensions that comply with SAP recommendations for the use of classic ABAP development technologies and the frameworks offered as classic SAP APIs
  • Level C contains custom extensions which cannot be qualified for Level B because of usage of arbitrary SAP internal objects. Under the condition that dedicated checks are performed before the release upgrade (following the changelog for SAP objects approach), these custom extensions can be considered conditionally clean.
  • Level D is not clean core and includes custom extensions with severe violations of SAP development recommendations like modifications, usage of not recommended SAP objects or extension technologies (e.g. implicit enhancements)."

Thanks for your sharing, it really help us great a lot.

Regards,

ZFiori.

entry.title: Re: Tax Compliance Tool
entry.content:
Hi @harishram 

Thank you for question.

The SAP Document and Reporting Compliance can manage most of the VAT compliance lifecycle. Ranging from data extraction and return preparation to electronic submission with workflow approvals, audit trail, and a compliance calendar to track deadlines. These Workflow notifications can be enabled through the Document Reporting Compliance dashboard or SAP workflow integration.

However, note that direct VAT payment tracking or automation is not a core Document Reporting Compliance function. Payment status can be monitored indirectly through integration with financial modules. Please note that the Run Statutory Reports app focuses only on report generation and submission, which means it does not cover the complete process and workflow steps.

In short, Document Reporting Compliance can handle endâ€‘toâ€‘end VAT reporting and submission with workflows and compliance tracking but payment management may require integration with other SAP modules.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP ABAP Classical Workflow: A complete guide (Part- 2)
entry.content:
Part-1 explains the classical workflow definition, technical requirements, BADI exits for standard transactions, business object and event creation, definitions of step types, container elements, and the binding process.

What will you learn from this blog?

Workflow builder creation in SWDD, element container creation, step type creation, binding process, and workflow debugging techniques.

Important transaction codes:

  • SWDD- Workflow builder creation or display
  • SBWP- SAP Business Workplace user inbox
  • PFTC- Create/Change/Display Tasks
  • SWIA- Display Workflow instances
  • SWUS- Test Workflow
  • SWDP- Workflow Log

Step 3.1: Creation of Container elements

 

The Element & Name should be the same as the business object event parameters and BADI 'lt_container' table as shown below.

 

All required element containers have been created to match the event parameters that were already defined in BO.

Step 3.2: Call the BO & Event in the workflow builder

The event parameter values are passed to the workflow builder through the workflow element container. 

Step 3.3: Create a Step type multiple condition 

As per our requirement, we have to send the user decision to the respective level of approvers based on NETPR, that already mentioned in part-1 blog.

I have split lower-level and higher-level approval by using the field 'LEVEL' values. 

For example: NETPR < 200.00 Rs then it is LEVEL1 (Lower Level),

                          NETPR > 200.00Rs then it is LEVEL2( Higher level).

Step 3.4: Create an activity step for the lower level to import the approver username from the GET_USER method in BO.

The method GET_USER is not a dialogue process, so enable the background processing option. In the container tab, we have to create the element containers for importing values from that method.

Now we have to complete the binding process for the activity step. I have exported the 'LEVEL' value to the method and imported the 'USERNAME' values returned from the method to the workflow builder. 

I have marked all element containers as both import and export types, so they are bound for both processes.

Step 3.5: Create Block & User decision steps for lower-level approvals:

Go to the dynamic processing tab and provide the multiline element for which you want line-by-line iteration. If you have any condition to stop the block (iteration), then you give that condition to the 'End condition' option.

In binding, it will create an element as a single line value.

Step 3.6: Create User decision

Create again the element containers import from workflow builder to this generic decision step to show those are in the user decision's description page, and complete the binding process.

As I already mentioned, I marked containers as both import and export, so they are bound for both processes.

Step 3.7: Process control

This is used to complete the workflow if any of the users reject the workflow at a particular level.

Now the lower-level approval workflow builder has been completed and shown as below.

Step 3.8: Create a Loop until the step for the high-level approver

For this step, I created two more element containers, EXIT_COND & USCOUNT.

 

Loop Until step:

EXITCOND- Initial value is 1 and it will increase in each loop iteration, if any of the approvers rejects the exit condition is set to 0 value.

USCOUNT- It is the total number of line items of the high-level approver internal table, the logic implemented in BO (part-1).

Step 3.9: Create an activity step for high-level approval

Create an element container to import the values from the GET_USER method. The difference between the low-level and high-level approval activity steps is:

  • Low-level approval â€“ We pass only the LEVEL parameter to fetch the approver usernames.
  • High-level approval, we pass the EXIT_COND along with the LEVEL parameter, which retrieves both the USCOUNT (user count) and a single approver username.

Complete the binding process.

Step 3.10: Create a user decision step for high-level approval

I used the same user decision task, which was already defined for lower-level approval, but the expression only differs.

Define expression on the Decision tab -> go to control tab and double click the task number -> create element container for this generic decision task in container tab -> Create description in description tab -> complete the binding in control tab.

Step 3.11: Create Container operation for both approver and reject decisions

  • If the user approves the work item, then the exit condition value should increase by using the container operation.
  • If the user rejects the work item, then the exit condition value should be 0 by using the container operation.

Approve process:

Reject Process:

Below are the completed steps of high-level approval

Below is an overall view of the workflow builder for this process.

Step 4: Execute and debug the workflow 

4.1: For low-level, the amount is below 200.00 Rs

Go to the business object, set the external break-point in the method GET_USER and change the user to SAP_WFRT through utilities-> settings -> ABAP EDITOR -> Debugging -> User 

Now changing the purchase order amount below 200 in the ME21/22N transaction.

Once the PO is saved, the break-point will be triggered like below.

The workflow user decision will trigger the below users one by one, i.e. the user decision will send to 2nd user after the first user approves.

Go to the transaction SBWP workflow inbox to approve/reject the user decision

In the below graphical workflow, we can able to see how the workflow is executed.

Now I have approved the work item from my inbox and see the current workflow log.

 

After the second user approved the work item.

Step 4.2: The level 1's Initial approver rejects the workflow 

This is how the step type 'Process Control' works to end the workflow.

Step 4.3: For high-level, the amount is below 200.00 Rs

In the above screenshot, we can see that the steps 'Fetch user' and 'User decision' are in a loop process. Let's see this in a graphical log.

Step 4.4: The level 2's Initial approver rejects the workflow 

 

Conclusion:

In this workflow builder, both the Block and Loop (Until) steps perform the same process. I just want to demonstrate how each of them works and how to set the exit condition when using a loop or a block.

Thanks for your time!

entry.title: Supercharge your view of Connected Business Partners
entry.content:
Introduction

Itâ€™s a common headache in SAP Business One: a company shows up in both ledgersâ€”vendor and customerâ€”and the net position isnâ€™t obvious during day-to-day work. In SAP Business One, link the two records using the 'Connected Customer/Vendor' field in BP Master Data (Accounting) so the relationship is explicit in the system. Once the records are linked, the standard toolsâ€”Dunning, Aging, and Internal Reconciliationâ€”become much more useful for seeing the combined relationship. The foundational aspects of handling these dual-role scenarios are valuable topics within the SAP Business One community. This article provides practical tips to enhance your control over these relationships.

In practice, most teams want faster, onâ€‘form visibility and safeguards. Here's what actually delivers that. This article delves into practical custom enhancements you can implement in SAP Business One. We'll cover how to empower users through:

  • Adding dynamic User-Defined Fields (UDFs) with live balance queries to critical forms like Outgoing Payments.
  • Implementing automated alerts to stay informed about key connected BP statuses.
  • Introducing transaction validations (via SBO_SP_TransactionNotification) to prevent issues, such as unnecessary payments to vendors who are also indebted to us as customers.

Connecting Business Partners

To link a customer and a vendor in SAP Business One, you can use the 'Connected Customer/Vendor' field within the accounting tab in Business Partner Master Data.

ðŸ’¡    The [ConnBP] database field in the OCRD table (Business Partner Master Data table) stores this link, and connect two distinct BP records.

Connected Vendor/Customer field in BP Master Data


Standard SAP Business One Tools for Managing Connected BPs

1.    Dunning Wizard: This tool can be configured to consider the connected relationship, providing a comprehensive report for both the primary BP and its connected counterparts by selecting the relevant options in the Dunning Wizard.

Dunning Wizard for connected BPs

2.    Customer/Vendor Aging Reports: These reports can also display all related documents for connected business partners, offering a unified view.

Customer/Vendor Aging Reports

3.    BP Internal Reconciliation: After reviewing the status of connected BPs (e.g., via Aging Reports or your custom query), the Internal Reconciliation feature can be used. While standard internal reconciliation typically applies to transactions within a single BP account, understanding the consolidated picture can guide manual journal entries or offsetting transactions that effectively reconcile the net position between a connected customer and vendor when submitting financial documents.

BP Internal Reconciliation

Internal Reconciliation

Going Beyond Standard Tools: Custom Enhancements for Superior Control

Beyond the builtâ€‘in functions, a few small customizations can give you tighter control in daily business:

1.    Custom Queries for Real-time Tracking & Proactive Alerts: You can create specific SQL queries to get an immediate overview of these relationships. This query can then be added to a user's 'My Menu' for quick access.

SELECT
    V.CardCode,
    V.CardName,
    C.CardCode,
    C.CardName,
    C.Balance AS CustomerBalance,
    V.Balance * -1 AS VendorBalance,
    V.Balance + C.Balance AS NetBalance
FROM OCRD V
INNER JOIN OCRD C ON V.CardCode = C.ConnBP
WHERE V.CardType = 'S' AND C.CardType = 'C'
ORDER BY V.CardCode;

ðŸ”—    This query provides a real-time snapshot of vendor-customer balances, aiding decision-making. The full code is on GitHub.

Connected BP Balance Query
Set up the balance query as a scheduled Alert: if the connected customer is overdue beyond your limit and the vendor has a payment due, AP gets a notification.

Setting up alerts for connected BP balances

Messages/Alerts Overview

ðŸ’¡   For scheduled alerts, ensure the SAP Business One Job Service (Alerts) component is installed and running on your server, and that Alert Management is enabled in General Settings.

2.    Implementing Transaction Validations via Stored Procedure

To prevent potential issues, such as making a large payment to a vendor who, as a connected customer, has a significant overdue balance, you can implement validations directly within SAP Business One transactions.

You can do this by adding a rule in the SBO_SP_TransactionNotification stored procedure: when an Outgoing Payment is added for a vendor, check the connected customer's overdue balance and block it if it's over your set limit. For example, when an Outgoing Payment is being added for a vendor, your stored procedure can check if this vendor has a connected customer account with an overdue balance. Based on predefined conditions (e.g., if the customer's overdue amount exceeds a certain threshold), the procedure can block the payment and display an error message to the user, prompting them to review the consolidated account status before proceeding.

ðŸ”—    This way, you avoid paying a supplier who is overdue as a customer. The complete stored procedure is available on GitHub.

Validations via Stored Procedure

3.    User-Defined Fields (UDFs) for Instant Visibility on Forms

Add UDFs on Outgoing Payments and drive them with Formatted Searches so that when a vendor is picked, the connected customer code and both balances appear instantly. When a vendor is selected, these UDFs can automatically display the code of any connected customer and their relevant balances.

Used-Defined Fields - Management

When a vendor is selected on the Outgoing Payment form, if they have a customer linked using the 'Connected Customer' field (in BP Master Data), the UDF for 'Connected BP Code' will auto-populate. Subsequently, other UDFs can display the connected customer's balance and the main vendor's balance using Formatted Searches linked to custom SQL queries.

Outgoing Payments form with UDFs for a linked customer

These UDFs use the Formatted Search feature to automatically fetch and display relevant data via linked SQL queries.

ðŸ’¡    To assign a Formatted Search to a UDF (or any field), select the field on the form and press 'Alt + Shift + F2'  to open the 'User-Defined Values - Setup' window.

Used-Defined Values

If no customer is connected to the selected vendor, the 'Connected BP Code' UDF will be empty, and the 'Customer Balance' UDF will display zero.

Outgoing Payments Form for a Vendor with No Linked Customer


Conclusion

Adding a few wellâ€‘chosen UDFs, a targeted alert, and one or two validation rules can make SAP Business One much easier to use when a vendor is also a customerâ€”giving your team a clearer view, more control, and fewer mistakes.

 

Prepared by

Amirhossein Tonekaboni
SAP Business One ERP Consultant

  • GitHub
  • LinkedIn
  • Allmylinks

SAP and SAP Business One are trademarks of SAP SE. This article is an independent publication by the author and not an official SAP statement.

entry.title: Re: Supplier login issues
entry.content:
Hi @JJ321 

That issue can occur due to several common scenarios in SAP Ariba registration. Let us walk through potential scenarios. Often, the error means the username or account the supplier tries to use is already linked to another supplier profile or buyer system. Ariba requires unique usernames, so attempts to reuse an existing username for a new registration cause error.


Another reason could be that the supplierâ€™s Ariba Business Network account might already be linked to your companyâ€™s buyer system but under a different supplier profile. If a new registration uses the same account but different profile information, it will fail with an account-linking error.


Also note that sometimes, multiple supplier organizations exist for the same company in your buyer system. One might be linked to the ANID, while others are not. Inviting the supplier to an unlinked profile causes errors until the accounts are reconciled.


There is also the possibility that the buyer system might have disabled automatic synchronization of additional users from the supplier organization and therefore may result in missing links between user accounts and buyer profiles.

To pinpoint potential solution, I suggest you evaluate the following:

  • Ensure to verify if your supplierâ€™s existing Ariba Business Network account (ANID) is already linked to your buyer system via supplier profiles.
  • Then check for duplicate or multiple supplier organizations under your buyer realm for the same company and unify or unlink as needed.
  • Ask your supplier to log in with their existing username and password rather than creating a new account. If necessary, reassign the supplierâ€™s questionnaire, event, or invitation to the correct user profile linked to the existing account.
  • Make sure your supplier uses Ariba Administrator tools Manage > Supplier and Customer Manager > Users to review linked accounts and resolve conflicts. If the supplier forgot their credentials, advise them to use the â€œForgot Username or Passwordâ€ process.
  • Finally, ensure that your supplier is not attempting to link the same ANID to multiple supplier organizations, which is not allowed. If synchronization is disabled by the buyer, enable or troubleshoot it in your system settings.

By following these steps, most of the errors faced while registering and linking can be resolved without requiring the supplier to create new accounts. If the issue persists, I recommend contacting SAP Ariba support with detailed account and error info.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: AI Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors: A New Level of Support for Recruiters
entry.content:
AI Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors: A New Level of Support for Recruiters

As someone who has spent years in Talent Acquisition, I've often found myself buried under stacks of resumes, trying to find that perfect candidate. It's repetitive work that can be exhausting. That's why I'm excited to share how SAP SuccessFactors' new AI-powered applicant screening is a game-changer for people like me in recruitment.

Simplifying the Screening Process

The AI feature in SAP SuccessFactors does more than just save timeâ€”it offers smart insights to help us zero in on the best candidates. The AI engine matches a candidate's skills to the job requirements not just by looking for exact matches but also by identifying related and transferable skills.

One of my favorite aspects of this tool is how it orders candidates, showing us who is the strongest match and who might be less relevant. Hereâ€™s how this benefits us as recruiters:

  • Efficient Screening: No more manually sifting through every resume.
  • Highlighting Strong Candidates: The best candidates rise to the top automatically.
  • Time-Saving: Weâ€™ve seen up to 80% reduction in screening time, and a 25% faster time-to-fill rate thanks to this feature.

Visit here: https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/ai-feature/3ea4fec4-1f6d-4865-9459-54ac5b337641

How It Worksâ€”The Basics

Here's a simple breakdown of how the system operates:

  1. Job Creation: The AI extracts skills from your job description. You have the option to tweak it to your liking.
  2. Application Processing: Resumes are scanned for matching, related, and missing skills.
  3. Recruiter Dashboard: It presents matches clearly, showing candidates ranked by their overall fit with the role.
  4. Customizable Usage: You can enable the feature for specific positions whenever you think it's needed.

Visit here: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-recruiting

Check Demo Video here: AI Applicant Screening

Why This Matters for Us

This technology is more than just helpfulâ€”it's transformative for recruiters:

  • Instant Shortlists: Quickly identify the right candidates without tedious manual effort.
  • Consistent Evaluation: Every candidate is assessed using the same criteria.
  • Improved Focus: We can spend more time engaging with candidates instead of doing repetitive, copy-paste tasks.
  • Informed Decisions: Thanks to transparent skill matching and ranking.

Part of a Broader AI Strategy

What's great is that this tool is part of a larger suite of AI offerings from SAP Business AI. Other features include:

  • Crafting better job descriptions
  • Generating interview questions tailored to individual roles
  • Recommending learning paths during onboarding

Visit here: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/explore-sap-successfactors-solutions/leveraging-ai-capabilities-in-sap-successfactors

Final Thoughts

For talent acquisition professionals, this isnâ€™t just another tech feature; it's a solution to many common hiring challenges. AI-assisted applicant screening in SAP SuccessFactors makes recruitment simpler and smarter, allowing us to focus on building more meaningful connections with the best candidates.

entry.title: Re: initial project stock upload 561Q is not reflected in...
entry.content:
You're absolutely rightâ€”this is a normal requirement in capital-intensive projects, engineering, construction, and defense sectors. Many organizations want visibility of:

  • Materials purchased or uploaded for a project
  • Stock sitting in inventory but earmarked for project use
  • Total committed valueâ€”even before consumption

To answer your question 'How others handle this', (to my knowledge), below are the most common approaches used across industries:

1. Use Commitment Tracking (Purchase Orders)

  • PO commitments are visible in project reports.
  • But once stock is received via 561Q, the commitment is clearedâ€”and visibility is lost.

2. Custom Report Linking Inventory to WBS

Develop a report that shows:

  • Project stock quantity and value (from MMBE or MBBS)
  • Linked WBS element

This gives visibility without affecting cost reports.

3. Statistical Cost Posting

  • Post a manual statistical actual cost to the WBS using KB11N.
  • Use a statistical cost element so it doesnâ€™t consume budget or distort actuals.
  • Document clearly that it represents unconsumed inventory.

4. Use Project Stock Valuation Reports

  • Reports like MBBS or S_ALR_87013558 can be customized to show stock value by WBS.
  • Not part of standard cost line items, but useful for project managers.

5. Enhanced Budgeting Logic

Some organizations extend budgeting logic to include inventory value as part of budget tracking. This requires custom development or integration with FM (Funds Management).

entry.title: Re: SXMSIF Configuration
entry.content:
Hi @naseemallika14 

Regarding your question on configuring. Let me walk you through it.

The Agency usually refers to the provider or authority responsible for the message or document exchange. It often represents a standardized body or organization defining the message formats or business rules.

The Schema defines the structure or format of the message or document. It corresponds to the XML schema or message type that governs how data elements are organized and validated in the integration.

The Party helps you identify the business partners involved in the message exchange, such as sender and receiver parties or systems. Each party represents a distinct entity or system participating in the communication scenario.

The Component typically means the technical component or system component responsible for sending or receiving the message. It helps direct and process the communication by mapping the interface to specific software components.

The SXMSIF fields help define the routing and processing of inbound and outbound messages by specifying who is sending or receiving which refers to the Party, under what Schema format, and which component or agency is involved.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: initial project stock upload 561Q is not reflected in...
entry.content:
In order to make already uploaded project stock (via 561Q) visible in project cost reportsâ€”ideally without custom development, you can consider the below options:

Option 1: Controlled 221Q â†’ 222Q with Statistical Cost Element

This is a refined version of the workaround you mentioned earlier, and while itâ€™s not ideal, it can be used strategically:

How it works is you post 221Q to issue material to the WBS element. This creates a cost posting and consumes budget. Immediately post 222Q to return the material to project stock. This reverses the quantity movement, but the cost posting remains visible in the project line item report. Importantly, use a statistical cost element for the 221Q posting. This ensures it doesnâ€™t consume budget or distort actual costs and the cost appears in the report, but is flagged as statistical.

Pros:
No custom report needed
Visible in standard project cost reports (CJI3, etc.)

Cons:
Requires careful configuration of cost elements
May confuse users if not documented properly

Option 2: Manual Actual Cost Posting via KB11N

If material movement isnâ€™t feasible or desirable, you can post a manual actual cost to the WBS using KB11N. Use a statistical cost element. Reference the material document number or stock value in the text

Pros:
Clean and auditable
No physical stock movement

Cons:
Manual effort
Doesnâ€™t reflect in inventory reports

Option 3: Reversal and Reposting with Correct Movement Type

If you're early in the project and stock hasnâ€™t been consumed, reverse the 561Q using 562Q. Repost using a movement type that allows cost posting (e.g., 201Q or 221Q). Assign the correct WBS element and cost element

Pros:
Clean reposting with proper accounting
Reflects in both inventory and cost reports

Cons:
Operational risk if stock has already been partially consumed
May require coordination with MM and Finance teams

My recommendations would be if you want visibility without disrupting inventory, the 221Q â†’ 222Q with statistical cost element is your best bet. Itâ€™s a controlled workaround that gives you reporting visibility while keeping the stock intact.

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration
As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025â€™s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

 

And the Winner Isâ€¦ PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform â€œLegal Easeâ€. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. â€œLegal Easeâ€ enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: â€œLegal Easeâ€ addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

 

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Letâ€™s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

 

Reflections and Whatâ€™s Next

The Hackathonâ€™s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

â€œIt is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

weâ€™ve seen incredible progress and innovation.â€

 

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, Iâ€™d love to hear from you in the comments.

 

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: Default Unit Pattern in sap/ui/core/format/NumberFormat now includes a non-breaking space
entry.content:
Intro

With a recent change in UI5 version 1.140, we have decided to include a non-breaking space in the default unit pattern. This way, the number and measure are guaranteed to stay in the same line, even with very small window sizes.

 

What's different?

If a value is formatted with sap/ui/core/format/NumberFormat.format and this function uses the default unit pattern (the fallback pattern if no other pattern is to be used) the resulting string will now include a non-breaking space between the number part and the measure part instead of a regular space. Using a respective type from sap/ui/model/type or sap/ui/model/odata/type to format values will also result in a string with a non-breaking space.

Example - Prior to the change:

  • Values to be formatted: ["50", "%"]
  • Formatted result: "50\u0020%"; \u0020 is a regular space character

Example - After to the change:

  • Values to be formatted: ["50", "%"]
  • Formatted result: "50\u00a0%"; \u00a0 is a non-breaking space character

                             

What does that mean for applications and tests?

Applications will only see a difference in the UI if the window size is small enough.
However tests might fail, as "50\u0020%" is not strict equal to "50\u00a0%": you need to adjust your test in this case.

entry.title: Re: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into the about our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
Hello,

regarding my question "rating of InApp-/KeyUser-Tools" -> this is answered. (Thank you Daniel!)

I got the hint to check the FAQ of the Whitepaper -> "QC1: How does the level concept translate to the ABAP language versions (ABAP Cloud for developers, ABAP Cloud for key users)?"

All customer objects with language version â€œABAP Cloud for Developersâ€ (language version 5) and â€œABAP Cloud for Key Usersâ€ (language version 2) are considered level A. This guarantees that these objects are only referencing released SAP objects.
In addition, there are objects in customer namespace which are generated when developing with ABAP Cloud for Key Users, which technically have ABAP classic language version, but which are still considered level A. With the correction from SAP note 3593439 these are also correctly detected.
All customer objects in levels B, C or D have language version ABAP classic.

Thank you and have a great day.

Regards, Thomas F!

entry.title: SAP Databricks: How to use AutoML to forecast sales data - Part 3
entry.content:
Part 1 â€“ SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 â€“ Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 â€“ How to use AutoML to forecast sales data
Part 4 â€“ End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 5 â€“ Create inferences and endpoints for application integration with SAP Build

 

SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud

With SAP Databricks you have access to an amazing set of capabilities to work with your BDC Data Products and other data.

 

 

Letâ€™s look at just one feature of SAP Databricks â€“ how we can use the AutoML Forecasting feature to predict time-series data.

 

How to use AutoML to forecast sales data

How can we analyse a dataset and make forecasts without having deep understanding of machine learning?

One way is to use AutoML which will automatically create the code and run machine learning experiments behind the scenes and then provide you with the best result at the end.

SAP Databricks has a feature to build AutoML models for you â€“ you just point it at the data and let it rip!

 

Data

For this exercise we are going to look at sales data and see if we can create an accurate forecast.

The S/4HANA system that I have available in my BDC formation has a sales_order data product available, however, after a quick investigation it's a very limited and small dataset with large multi-month gaps in the data, which is not a realistic dataset for forecasting.

For the purposes of this blog post, let's create some realistic sample data instead.

So even with AutoML - there is no excuse but to learn about your data!

 

We will create sample data and save it as a delta table: workspace.default.demo_product_sales_forecast.

 

Note:
The SAP Databricks catalog (or Unity Catalog you will see it called) structures artefacts in a format like:
- Catalog (defaulted to the name workspace but you can create many catalogs)
            - Schema (your initial schema will be called default)
                        - Table, Model, etc

 

The dataset includes several different products, and the amount sold each month over a multi-year period to consider any seasonality effects.

We will look to train a forecast model using SAP Databricks' built-in Serverless AutoML Forecast capability.

 

Note: SQL function ai_forecast()
You can also perform forecasting with a prophet based model using the SQL function ai_forecast. It only works on the serverless SQL compute however, so you cannot execute it from a Notebook which runs on the all-purpose serverless compute.
Check the ai_forecast() documentation for details and limitations.
Depending on the complexity of your data, this AutoML technique can provide better results and offers more tuning options.

 

Sample dataset

In your SAP Databricks workspace click the â€œCreateâ€ button and create a new python notebook.

Add a new python cell containing the following to install some modules we will use later:

%pip install databricks-automl-runtime prophet
%restart_python

And now the cell for sample data creation:

# Build a sales data set for forecasting

import pandas as pd, numpy as np
from itertools import product
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 1. CONFIG â€“ tweak to taste
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
skus       = ["SKU_A", "SKU_B", "SKU_C", "SKU_D"]
price_map  = {"SKU_A": 25.0, "SKU_B": 40.0, "SKU_C": 33.0, "SKU_D": 18.0}
start, end = "2019-01-01", "2025-12-01"            # 7 full years, monthly freq
rng        = np.random.default_rng(42)             # reproducible

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 2. SYNTHETIC DATA FABRICATION
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
dates = pd.date_range(start, end, freq="MS")        # Month-Start stamps
# WEEKLY
# dates = pd.date_range("2019-01-07", "2025-12-29", freq="W-MON")
# or DAILY
# dates = pd.date_range("2019-01-01", "2025-12-31", freq="D")
rows  = []
for sku, ts in product(skus, dates):
    #   volume dynamics ------------------------------------------------------
    base   = {"SKU_A":380, "SKU_B":240, "SKU_C":310, "SKU_D":700}[sku]
    trend  = {"SKU_A":  6, "SKU_B":  9, "SKU_C":  4, "SKU_D": -3}[sku] * (ts.year-2019)
    seas   = 80 * np.sin(2*np.pi*ts.month/12 + {"SKU_A":0, "SKU_B":1,
                                                "SKU_C":2, "SKU_D":3}[sku])
    promo  = 120 if ts.month in (11, 12) else 0     # holiday lift
    noise  = rng.normal(0, 40)
    units  = max(0, int(base + trend + seas + promo + noise))
    
    #   revenue = units Ã— price Â± small discount noise -----------------------
    net_amt = round(units * price_map[sku] * rng.uniform(0.97, 1.03), 2)
    
    rows.append((sku, ts, units, net_amt))

df = pd.DataFrame(rows, columns=["SKU",              #   â† series identifier
                                 "SalesOrderDate",   #   â† time column
                                 "UnitsSold",        #   â† target 1
                                 "TotalNetAmount"])  #   â† target 2 (optional)

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 3. LAND AS A DELTA TABLE
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
(spark.createDataFrame(df)
      .write.format("delta").mode("overwrite")
      .saveAsTable("demo_product_sales_forecast"))

# Quick visual sanity-check (optional)
display(spark.table("demo_product_sales_forecast")
              .orderBy("SalesOrderDate", "SKU")
              .limit(12))

Execute these cells and you will now have a new table in the catalog called demo_product_sales_forecast.

 

AutoML Forecast â€“ configure and train

Now we have our sample data generated by our python notebook, letâ€™s use SAP Databricks inbuilt function to create a machine learning model using AutoML.

 

Steps within the SAP Databricks cockpit:

  1. Navigate to AI/ML -> Experiments in the left menu bar and click the forecasting (preview) box


     



  2. Populate the required fields.
    Enter workspace.default.demo_product_sales_forecast as the training data (this is the sample data table we previously created with a python notebook)

  3. Choose SalesOrderDate as the Time Column

  4. Choose UnitsSold (or TotalNetAmount) for the Target Column (the value we want to be able to predict)

  5. Choose Monthly for Forecast Frequency

  6. Set 12 months for the Forecast Horizon

  7. Enter workspace.default as the prediction path (or any other Unity Catalog path of your choosing) and demo_product_sales_forecast_predictions as the prediction table

  8. Enter the location where you want the model saved and its name (e.g. workspace.default and sales_forecast)

  9. Under Advanced Options, choose column SKU as the time-series identifier (IMPORTANT! Since this dataset covers multiple different products)

 

Finally, click Start Training.

 

With this sample dataset, training can take around 20mins.
AutoML is pre-processing the data, tuning a forecasting model
by building many different types of models with different 
hyperparameters and finally training (fit) on the data using 
the best model and parameters.

 

See it creating experiments as it tunes the model now:

 

SAP Databricks uses the MLFlow frameworks for MLOps, which enables history to be captured and for you to create reproducible workflows.

 

Training results

At the end of the training run the best model is chosen based on a hyperparameter search and saved (and registered) to the unity catalog in SAP Databricks.

 

A table of predictions is created as a result (you provided the name when configuring AutoML). The best trained model is also saved and registered into the unity catalog (with the name you entered e.g. sales_forecast).

 

View the forecast result

You can switch back to your python notebook (or open the SAP Databricks SQL editor) to view the data with:

%sql
select * from demo_product_sales_foreacast_predictions

 

Visual sanity check.

We can use the following code cell in your notebook to plot the historical (training) data and extend it with the 12-month forecast.

import pandas as pd, matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# â”€â”€ grab data â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
hist_tbl = "demo_product_sales_forecast"
pred_tbl = "demo_product_sales_foreacast_predictions"   # name from AutoML wizard

hist = spark.table(hist_tbl).toPandas()
pred = spark.table(pred_tbl).toPandas()

# ensure date columns are pandas Timestamps
hist["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(hist["SalesOrderDate"])
pred["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(pred["SalesOrderDate"])

# â”€â”€ plot per SKU â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
for sku in hist["SKU"].unique():
    h = hist[hist["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    p = pred[pred["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 4))
    
    ax.plot(h["SalesOrderDate"], h["UnitsSold"], label="actual", linewidth=2)
    ax.plot(p["SalesOrderDate"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"],
            label="forecast", linestyle="--")
    
    ax.fill_between(
        p["SalesOrderDate"],
        p["predicted_UnitsSold_lower"],
        p["predicted_UnitsSold_upper"],
        alpha=0.25,
        label="95 % Confidence"
    )
    
    ax.set_title(f"Units Sold â€“ {sku}")
    ax.set_xlabel("Date")
    ax.set_ylabel("Units")
    ax.legend()
    ax.grid(True)
    
    plt.show()

 

Output for one of the products:

 

We can see it looks pretty good and has captured the cyclical nature of the sales data well.

 

Letâ€™s now back-test the forecast to see how good it works and compare it to the last 12 months of training data. We can do this by cutting off the training data 12 months early and forecasting for that cut-off 12 months.

Note: what we are doing here is actually leaking training data into our test which is bad practice in a real life scenario but it's just a quick way to visualise how the forecast works. In real life we should carve out some of our training data (e.g. the last months or year maybe) and perform the below test on that data.

Use this cell to plot actual vs. prediction.

# ðŸ“Š Back-test: forecast last 12 months per SKU and plot
import mlflow, pandas as pd, numpy as np, matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# â”€â”€ 1. LOAD THE REGISTERED MODEL â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
uc_model_path     = "workspace.default.sales_forecast"     # fully-qualified UC model
model_version_uri = f"models:/{uc_model_path}@most_recent"

mlflow.set_registry_uri("databricks-uc")                  # point MLflow at UC
model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(model_version_uri)       # pulls pipeline incl. featurizer

# â”€â”€ 2. HISTORICAL DATA â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
hist = (spark.table("demo_product_sales_forecast")
           .toPandas()
           .sort_values(["SKU", "SalesOrderDate"]))
hist["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(hist["SalesOrderDate"])

# â”€â”€ 3. HOLD-OUT = last 12 rows per SKU â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
holdout_idx = hist.groupby("SKU").tail(12).index
score_df    = hist.loc[holdout_idx].copy().reset_index(drop=True)
train_df    = hist.drop(index=holdout_idx)

# â”€â”€ 4. PREDICT ON HOLD-OUT â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
features = score_df.drop(columns=["UnitsSold"])           # only drop the target
yhat     = model.predict(features).reset_index(drop=True) # returns a Series named 'yhat'
score_df["predicted_UnitsSold"] = yhat                    # attach forecast column

# (optional) prediction intervals if the pipeline supports them:
# try:
#     pi = model.predict_interval(features, coverage=0.95).reset_index(drop=True)
#     score_df = pd.concat([score_df, pi], axis=1)
# except AttributeError:
#     pass

# â”€â”€ 5. SMAPE helper â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
def smape(actual, forecast):
    denom = np.abs(actual) + np.abs(forecast)
    return np.mean(np.where(denom == 0, 0, 200 * np.abs(actual - forecast) / denom))

# â”€â”€ 6. PLOT PER SKU â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
for sku in hist["SKU"].unique():
    h = hist[hist["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    p = score_df[score_df["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")

    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 4))
    ax.plot(h["SalesOrderDate"], h["UnitsSold"],
            label="actual", lw=2)
    ax.plot(p["SalesOrderDate"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"],
            label="back-test forecast", lw=2, ls="--", color="orange")

    # uncomment if interval columns exist
    # if {"predicted_UnitsSold_lower", "predicted_UnitsSold_upper"}.issubset(p.columns):
    #     ax.fill_between(p["SalesOrderDate"],
    #                     p["predicted_UnitsSold_lower"],
    #                     p["predicted_UnitsSold_upper"],
    #                     color="orange", alpha=0.15, label="95 % PI")

    sku_smape = smape(p["UnitsSold"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"])
    #ax.set_title(f"{sku} â€“ Back-test SMAPE: {sku_smape:.2%}")
    ax.set_title(f"{sku} â€“ Back-test SMAPE: {sku_smape/100:.2%}")
    ax.set_xlabel("Date"); ax.set_ylabel("Units")
    ax.legend(); ax.grid(True)
    plt.show()

 

 

Conclusion

Forecasting time-series data with SAP Databricks is made far easier thanks to AutoML which takes away the work of cleaning your data (pre-processing step); hyperparameter tuning by building many model experiments and capturing them in MLFow (tuning step) and finally training the best model architecture to suit your data (training step).

You might also be wondering â€“ why â€“ why bother with this and instead use an LLM to do it all? Well, the answer is that LLMâ€™s just arenâ€™t that good at working with tabular data. For very small datasets â€“ absolutely â€“ throw it into ChatGPT for some analysis. But for real scenarios we still rely on classic machine learning approaches as shown hereâ€¦

entry.title: Future of Feature Toggles
entry.content:
Dear all, 

I am currently member in a migration project to S4 Hana.
We currently use a self-developed framework that also has a "feature toggle" functionality.

When I looked into the topic of feature toggles a few years ago, I discovered that SAP has an own implementation of feature toggles in S4.

Now I wanted to test this and the result is:

  • Legacy feature toggles are marked as deprecated in Eclipse.
  • Switch-Based Feature Toggles cannot be created on customer systems.

What is the future here in on premise / private cloud?

The idea of a feature toggle is a temporary switch. As soon as the feature has been fully developed and rolled out to all users, it should be removed.
Therefore, in my opinion, there is nothing to be said against the usage of "legacy feature toggles", as they are meant only to be used temporarily in the code.

In case the framework is deleted by SAP, the legacy feature toggles should have been removed and deleted again following the idea of clean code.

At least I do not find "cl_feature_toggle"  in the current simplification database :-).

What's your opinion?
Is there a better alternative?

Regards
JÃ¼rgen

entry.title: Re: Restricting BNK_MONI T-code
entry.content:
BNK_MONI is a monitoring transaction, not a posting or execution transaction. Itâ€™s primarily used to view payment statuses and batches.

SAP designed it to check F_STAT_MON, which includes fields like:

  • Authorization group
  • Payment medium status
  • Payment run status

It does not include company code as a restriction field, which means you can't directly restrict access by company code using standard authorization objects.

Here are some approaches and Best Practices which you can also try

1. Authorization Groups
Assign different authorization groups to payment batches based on company code. Then restrict F_STAT_MON by authorization group. This requires customizing your payment configuration to tag batches appropriately.

2. Custom Enhancement (BAdI or User Exit)
Implement a custom check via enhancement in BNK_MONI or related function modules. You can intercept the selection logic and restrict based on userâ€™s company code authorization.

3. Role-Based UI Restriction
If you're using SAP Fiori apps, you can apply restriction types at the business catalog level. For example, restrict by company code using the â€œCompany Codeâ€ restriction field in the role definition.

entry.title: Employee data review and farewell message task performed by HRADMIN in offboarding
entry.content:
Hi Everyone

I created a business rule where the Employee Data Review is performed by HRADMIN, and the Write Farewell Message in Offboarding task is also performed by HRADMIN.

Steps to configure:

  1. Create the Business Rule

  2. Under Onboarding General Settings, create a Responsible Group and assign all country-specific dynamic groups to it. Then, assign this responsible group to the Farewell Message task.

  3. Create country-specific dynamic groups and assign them to the responsible group you created

 

Regards,

Garima Saxena

entry.title: Re: SAP CIS Identity Provisioning Service integration with SAP HANA Cloud, HANA Database
entry.content:
Dear @pavlomelnyk ,

Thank you for your excellent blog post on setting up the provisioning framework to SAP HANA Cloud DB via IPS. Following your guidance, we successfully implemented the scenario.

We now have a new requirement to assign an additional Identity Provider (SAML) to the user record for an SAC Live Data connection. Our goal is to achieve this through IPS provisioning by setting the SAC SAML IdP in addition to the existing JWT provider.

However, it appears that the SCIM schema supports only one IdP entry per user. When we attempted to provision an additional SAML IdP via IPS, it overwrote the existing JWT provider in the user record. We confirmed that it is possible to maintain an additional IdP manually via the UI, which we did for testing purposes.

To verify this, we performed a GET request via Postman to check the SCIM schema for the user. Unfortunately, the additional IdP did not appear in the schema, leading us to conclude that only one IdP can be provisioned via IPS.

We have also opened a ticket with SAP Support. While they are currently investigating, they advised us to post this question in the SAP Community as well. We believe this may be a broader use case, as there are scenarios where users would need both IdPs:

  • JWT for SSO access at the DB level

  • SAML IdP for consuming data via SAC Live Data connection

Do you have any experience or insights regarding this requirement?

Thank you in advance for your feedback.

Kind regards,

Alex

entry.title: Re: Determining Directory Path of Solution Management Doc...
entry.content:
Hello
In Solman 7.2 system documents are stored by default in table SMDCONT. Every Document has a unique LOIO ID - this is stored in table SMDLOIO. Every changes to a document created a new version and a new PHIO ID - those are stored in table SMDPHIO.
The file size of a document can be seen in table SMDPHF - by providing the PHIOID. 

Generally to reduce table size of SMDCONT - you may refer to Note
https://me.sap.com/notes/0003317599
2956173 - Delete orphan documents in Solution Documentation with SOLMAN_UNUSED_72_DOCUMENTS

Best Regards
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Batch Derivation and Co-Product
entry.content:
Why it is not working is because, SAPâ€™s standard batch derivation setup assumes:

  • One receiver batch (typically the header material).
  • Multiple sender batches (components).

This is known as pull derivation, and itâ€™s designed to derive characteristics from components to the main product. Co-products, however, are treated differently in the process order structure and may not be included in the default derivation event unless explicitly configured.

You can try the below methods

Use Push Derivation
Push derivation allows one sender to multiple receivers, which is ideal for co-products. You must configure condition records for push derivation using transaction DVC1 or DVCO. Set the derivation event to trigger during confirmation or goods receipt.

Maintain Condition Records for Co-Product

In transaction DVCO, create a condition record where:

  • Sender = Component C1
  • Receiver = Co-product SF1
  • Assign characteristic C1

Ensure the derivation rule is set to static or dynamic based on your needs.

Activate Derivation Event for Co-Product
Go to SPRO â†’ Logistics - General â†’ Batch Management â†’ Derivation of Batch Data â†’ Define Derivation Events. Ensure the event (e.g., goods receipt or confirmation) is active for co-product derivation.

Check Batch Where-Used List Activation
Batch derivation relies on the Batch Where-Used List (BaWU). Make sure synchronous posting is enabled so the system tracks sender-receiver relationships correctly.

entry.title: SAP EHS Environment Management - environmental responsibility and regulatory compliance
entry.content:
To assure environmental responsibility, regulatory compliance, and sustainable operations, SAP offers a comprehensive suite of solutions within SAP Environment, Health, and Safety â€“ Environment Management, tailored to the needs of environmental managers, compliance specialists, and sustainability leaders.

At the heart of these solutions is the ability to centrally manage, monitor, and report on environmental aspects across the enterprise â€“ from air emissions to regulatory obligations and waste streams â€“ ensuring alignment with both legal requirements and corporate sustainability strategies.

Emission Management enables organizations to track, calculate, and report air pollutant and greenhouse gas emissions in line with local and international standards. By integrating operational data, it facilitates accurate emissions inventories, regulatory submissions, and transparent reporting, supporting both environmental impact reduction and corporate climate objectives.

Compliance Management provides a structured approach to managing all environmental obligations â€“ whether arising from legislation, permits, or internal policies. Through a central repository for requirements and integrated task tracking, the solution reduces compliance risks, ensures timely execution, and enables clear documentation to demonstrate regulatory adherence.

Waste Management covers the complete lifecycle of waste handling â€“ from identification and classification to transport, treatment, and final disposal â€“ ensuring compliance with environmental regulations and corporate sustainability commitments. It streamlines waste tracking, documentation for hazardous and non-hazardous materials, and reporting for regulatory or internal purposes.

Below, you will find an introductory video for each of these topics, offering a concise overview of the solution scope and a glimpse into the user experience through mini demos. These videos highlight how SAP EHS Environment Management empowers organizations to operate sustainably, maintain compliance, and enhance environmental performance.

entry.title: Re: Unable to settle WBS Element
entry.content:
The root cause and the error you're facing likely stems from how SAP treats cost element category 31:

These are secondary cost elements, used internally for allocations and RA calculations.
They do not post directly to FI, and are typically used in RA versions (configured via transaction OKG9) to calculate WIP or revenue recognition.

If you're seeing an error during WBS processing, it may be because:

The system is trying to settle or post using this technical cost element, which isn't allowed.
Or, the RA key or version is misconfigured, causing the system to misinterpret the cost element's role.

Below are the recommended approach

1. Review RA Version in OKG9
Confirm that the cost element is assigned correctly to a line ID in the RA version. Ensure the line ID is marked as technical and not intended for settlement or posting.

2. Check Posting Rules in OKG8
The actual posting to FI happens via OKG8, where you define which cost elements post to which GL accounts. Make sure the technical cost element is not included in posting rules unless explicitly required.

3. Validate Settlement Profile
Go to CJ2B or CJ20N and check the settlement profile on the WBS element. Ensure it allows settlement only for valid cost elements and not technical ones.

4. Run RA Simulation (KKA2)
Use KKA2 to simulate RA and see how the system is treating the cost element. This can help pinpoint if the error is due to incorrect cost element usage or missing configuration.
